overview: The key focus of this subject is the foundations of systems analysis for designing and certifying learning-based and artificial intelligence (AI) algorithms for robotics applications. These foundations are based on the formulations and frameworks for the modelling and analysis of cyber-physical systems, such as the feedback interconnection of the physical robot, the noisy sensor data it uses to understand its environment, and the algorithm it runs to learn through exploration and to exploit its knowledge to maximise performance. The subject focuses on both existing applications of decision-making and learning algorithms to consumer and industrial robotics, as well as emerging applications of reinforcement learning and AI for robotics.
Topics covered are at the intersection of automatic control and artificial intelligence, including:
Cyber-physical feedback system formulation, such as: black-box and grey-box modelling, stability and robustness safety requirements, hierarchical and network control architectures.
Safety and convergence guarantees for model-based methods, such as: learning models from data; adaptive control schemes; stability and robustness of PID and MPC control approaches.
Connections between optimal control and reinforcement learning formulations for robotics.
Reinforcement learning for robotics, such as: actor-critic methods, on-policy versus off-policy learning, sample efficiency, transferring simulation-based learning to real-world robots
intended learning outcomes: Construct and critique systems-level formulations and architectures for robotic systems to perform tasks, using tools such as block diagrams and Markov decision processes.
Analyse and implement model-based methods for providing stability and performance, such as: PID, MPC, system identification, or adaptive control schemes
Analyse and implement reinforcement learning (RL) methods for discrete-time dynamical systems with continuous spaces

Appriase and combine the strengths of  multiple decision-making and learning algorithms for implementation on real-world systems, including an interdisciplinary perspective on using concepts and approaches from the engineering and computer science domains to develop an integrated solution.
Communicate and collaborate on AI and decision-making projects through formats such as: technical reports, presentations, and informational videos, and reflection
Differentiate and critique the variety of definitions, applications, and safety implications of AI for engineering systems

additional pre-requisite: Admission into one of the following: MC-ELECENG Master of Electrical Engineering, MC-MTRNENG Master of Mechatronics Engineering
Note: the following subject/s can also be taken concurrently (at the same time)
Admission into one of the following: MC-IT Master of Information Technology, MC-SOFTENG Master of Software Engineering, MC-CS Master of Computer Science
Note: the following subject/s can also be taken concurrently (at the same time)

assessments.description: Individual upskilling with hardware and software, in the form of demonstration, oral test, log book, and/or code submission. Learning Outcomes (ILOs) 1-4 are addressed in this assessment. 10 hours

Continuous individual assessment of team project work, in the form of reports, presentations and/or videos, not exceeding 40 pages per student over the semester. Approximately 60 hours of work per student. 4 submissions between Weeks 3-14, spaced approximately 3-4 weeks.  Intended Learning Outcomes (ILOs) 1-5 are addressed in this assessment.. 60 hours (of work required)

Individual presentation. ILO 5-6 are addressed in this assessment. 10 minutes. Hurdle requirement:. Students must score above a hurdle requirement on the total of the individual upskilling, individual presentation, mid-semester test and written exam. This hurdle requirement will be set by the Board of Examiners and be no higher than 50%.

Progress Test. ILOs 1-3 are addressed in this assessment.. 1 hours. Hurdle requirement:. Students must score above a hurdle requirement on the total of the individual upskilling, individual presentation, mid-semester test and written exam. This hurdle requirement will be set by the Board of Examiners and be no higher than 50%.

Final Exam. ILOs 1-4 are addressed in this assessment.. 2 hours. Hurdle requirement:. Students must score above a hurdle requirement on the total of the individual upskilling, individual presentation, mid-semester test and written exam. This hurdle requirement will be set by the Board of Examiners and be no higher than 50%

Semester 2.Contact hours: 60 hours, comprising of two hours of lectures and three hours of workshops per week for 12 weeks

Prescribed texts: There are no specifically prescribed or recommended texts for this subject.

Subject notes: The subject is designed and delivered using project-based learning pedagogies. Students in this subject two projects in small team, one of which is hands-on with a real-world robot. Lecture/lectorial sessions occur weekly, with the content in the first half of semester focused on implementation of AI methods, and the content in the second half of semester focused on theory that facilitates faster and more efficient implementation. Workshops occur throughout the semester to support the projects and practice the lecture/lectorial content. The workshop content transitions from guided upskilling with hardware and AI algorithms, to more open-ended project work.

Students are provided with a functioning robot that has an accompanying wiki with documentation and tutorials for how to interact with the sensors and actuators of the robot. Lecture/lectorial and guided-workshop materials provide the framework and upskilling necessary to implement AI alogorithms for robotics, both in simulation and on the real hardware.

The premise of the subject is gain hands on experience with cutting edge AI algorithms for robotics (e.g., Model Predictive Control (MPC) for nonlinear systems, and Reinforcement Learning (RL) for continuous-space models. Moreover, the subject focuses on bringing togother students from multiple diciplines to work together with the strengths of each displince (Electrical Engineering, Mechatronics, Computer Science, IT), which is representative of industry team that graduates will be part of when working on AI algorithms for robotics applications. Additionally, industry guest are brought in to discuss how advanced AI algorithms are currently being deployed and developed in their sector.

About the Community Access Program (CAP): This subject is available through theCommunity Access Program(also called Single Subject Studies) which allows you to enrol in single subjects offered by the University of Melbourne, without the commitment required to complete a whole degree.
Entry requirements including prerequisites may apply. Please refer to theCAP applications pagefor further information.

Available to Study Abroad and/or Study E: This subject is available to students studying at the University from eligible overseas institutions on exchange and study abroad. Students are required to satisfy any listed requirements, such as pre- and co-requisites, for enrolment in the subject.
